Correct.  It's a thought experiment.  You wouldn't likely implement it
=
like that, since it would be such a waste of computation resources. 
But th=
ink of the concept.  Picture a 2-dimensional 'space' where
individuals are =
plotted somewhere in that space.  Now imagine applying
the reproduction des=
cribed.  Suddenly, there is better than 10 times
as many points.  We know f=
rom the evaluation of the last generation
what 'areas' of the search space =
are of higher significance (fitness),
so we concentrate our search there.  =
We select 'points' in the search
space and say "let's test here".  Then we =
select the individual that
represents that point in space.

The problem wit=
h the current method is that you choose individuals
that are close to that =
area, breed them, and HOPE that you get an
offspring that is in the area th=
at is worth searching.  Unfortunately,
that isn't necessarily what happens.=
  You could breed two individuals
that are on opposite sides of the ideal s=
olution, hoping that their
offspring would be in the area right in the midd=
le.  But it could end
up being actually somewhere way off in left field.

W=
hereas by defining the individuals and then selecting the one that is
in th=
e 'space' you are interested in persuing, that goes away.  Now,
it is a tot=
al WASTE to generate that many individuals, of course. 
What would be bette=
r would be to identify the space you are interested
in, and then be able to=
 deliberately merge the two individuals in such
a way as to create an indiv=
idual in that exact location in the search
space.  And if you can tell me h=
ow to do that with a reasonable amount
of CPU cycles, GREAT!  But in the me=
an time, generating a whole bunch
of extra genomes and then selecting the o=
nes that are the most
interesting seems to me to be a more pragmatic approa=
ch to
accomplishing that goal.

Think of the 10k new individuals as 'Where =
COULD we go from here?'. 
Then the sampling of them as 'Where WILL we go fr=
om here?'

But yes, it does pre-suppose that it is possible to define an
n-=
dimensional space that has structure related to the ability of
individuals =
to solve the problem.  Is that achievable?   Is there a
way to define a 'po=
int' in space using N data points, and having them
actually be related in s=
uch a way that the measurement of 'distance'
between points actually bears =
some useful result?  It is assumed that
two individuals that are very close=
 in structure should have very
similar fitness.  Thus, it is assumed that s=
uch a 'structure' exists. 
So how can we effectively model it such that we =
can use what we know
from what we have tested to be able to identify where =
to test next? 
Hill climbing, for example, assumes this very ability.

Here=
's a silly thought.  Let me just throw it out there.

Imagine creating a ne=
ural network whose inputs are the structure of a
neural network.  For each =
individual with that topology that you test,
pass their weights to this net=
work, and use back propagation to adjust
the weights of that meta-network. =
 Once the meta-network achieves a
measure of success at predicting the fitn=
ess of an actual network, we
can use the 'model' that exists inside that ne=
twork to identify where,
based on that model, would be the best area in the=
 search space (for
that topology) to look.

The whole idea is 'more efficie=
nt searches'.  The idea of hill
climbing rests on the assumption that an im=
provement is always a good
idea.  But the reality of a local optima proves =
that the assumption is
wrong.  So we look for ways around it, but without l=
etting go of that
basic assumption.

But if instead of making assumptions w=
e actually make models of our
search, perhaps we CAN be more efficient for =
those more complicated
searches where the search space is full of local opt=
ima.

Just throwing out ideas...
